subSubSection.paragraph:
Neochauliodes rotundatus Tjeder, 1937
. Ark. Zool. 29A: 4. Type locality: Sichuan (Pao–ning–fu).

Diagnosis. Head yellowish brown to dark brown; pronotum yellowish brown with pair of dark brown vittae on lateral margins; wing hyaline with obscure brownish marks, median transverse band rather broad; male tenth sternum in lateral view with apex strongly inflated, in ventral view with basal margin with V–shaped incision.
Male. Body length 17–31 mm ; forewing length 35–39 mm , hindwing length 31–35 mm .
Head yellowish brown to dark brown. Compound eyes brown, ocelli pale yellow with black inner margin. Antenna dark. Mouthparts yellowish brown, sometimes with mandibles much darker.

Prothorax yellowish brown, dorsally with pair of dark brown vittae on lateral margins; meso– and metathorax pale brown with lateral portions much darker. Legs blackish brown with short, dense, yellowish setae; femora sometimes pale brown, tarsal claws reddish brown. Wings ( Fig. 7 ) hyaline with brownish marks; pterostigma short, pale yellow. Forewing with a short brown stripe proximal and distal to pterostigma, and with one brown mark on proximal costal area; proximal marks small and sometimes obscure; median transverse band broad and sometimes faded, extending from C to M; distal marks mostly connected with each other, much paler or absent. Hindwing similarly marked, but with proximal half hyaline. Veins brown. Rs four–branched, R 2 distally three–branched, three crossveins between R 1 and Rs; M two–branched; 1A two– branched.
Female. Body length 29–40 mm ; forewing length 40–45 mm , hindwing length 37–41 mm .

Specimens examined.

Distribution. China ( Beijing , Chongqing , Gansu , Hebei , Heilongjiang , Henan , Hubei , Shannxi, Sichuan ).

Remarks. This species appears to be closely related to
N. nigris
in having similar male genitalia, but can be easily separated from
N. nigris
by the faded wing patterns and the subquadrate female gonocoxite. In
N. nigris
, the wing patterns are distinct and the female gonocoxite is foliate with the ventrodistal margin incised. Currently, only
N. rotundatus
extends to northeastern China , representing the northernmost distribution of
Neochauliodes
.
